title: Catholic group spent millions on app data that tracked gay priests

last_post.content:
This is a "holy shit" story with an emphasis on the holy: https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2023/03/09/catholics-gay-priests-grindr-data-bishops/

To out priests using Grindr, a conservative group spent "millions of dollars" on mobile app tracking data.

This whole saga has been one of the most illuminating case studies in the privacy harms that can come from "aggregated" and "de-identified" data being freely sold in the marketplace.

title: Hachette v. Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The lawsuit we're fighting isn’t just about the Internet Archive. It will determine the future of all libraries & their patrons, including those with print disabilities. #Accesstoknowledge for diverse communities will be impacted 🌍

Over the next 20 days until we go to court, we’ll be giving you 20 reasons to care about this lawsuit. We can’t wait to introduce you to the teachers, doctors, journalists & many more who rely on our lending library #EmpoweringLibraries https://www.eff.org/cases/hachette-v-internet-archive

title: Signal is for everyone, and everyone is different

last_post.content:
This blog post by @signalapp is excellent. It talks about how there is "no such thing as global communication norms". Some features, such as stickers or voice memos are massively more popular in some regions than others.

This is something to take into account of what's going to happen if/when the fediverse starts to scale.

https://signal.org/blog/signal-is-for-everyone/

title: Inside the Suspicion Machine

last_post.content:
An #algorithm determined which welfare recipients in Rotterdam, Netherlands should be investigated for benefits fraud.

Reporters got access to the system, reconstructed it, and tested how it works.

They found serious ethnicity and gender discrimination. A must read: https://www.wired.com/story/welfare-state-algorithms/

title: Upwelling: Combining real-time collaboration with version control for writers.

last_post.content:
It was an immense privilege to work with the very fine folks at Ink & Switch on Upwelling, an exploration of writer-focused collaboration tools: https://www.inkandswitch.com/upwelling/

Collaboration tools for software developers (git, etc) have been deeply explored and are rich in diversity and features. Writers' tools: not so much. With Upwelling, we leaned into recent advances in CRDTs to experiment with possible UX patterns for collaboration on prose.

title: Opinion | How ChatGPT Hijacks Democracy

last_post.content:
In 2017, bots submitted over a million comments opposing net neutrality to the FCC. In my view, this man-in-the-middle attack on democracy has been one of the most under-discussed of the past decade.

Somehow last January I missed this piece from Nathan Sanders and Bruce Schneier on how LLMs will turbocharge the threat of similar exploits.

Below, paywall-free link.
https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/15/opinion/ai-chatgpt-lobbying-democracy.html?unlocked_article_code=61TJbKENncOjj4w0qdmX6R_JU9qkQgfcQhqrcslgJBgUWRr34GgvJnhcTuBrCqNMFgMB3tKIJy1TSWLn2gCMbe56i9r9ij9dlwWbiKaF6ht0nlKU2UYd2gNOB1lhcM0yd4nQ8bwRWYVRIPxvaaGqYI9c-KfCyZgPP2u3m3GbMUem-XTDYNKROjD5Aaub68qbX5d9cJRGYeIYpDOXIE6U01rRZXJUCZTOE8_GbD-DelTGJOiJ11HfeSTaHQOylJB2NbdMYr8zNM6U4ToAIN8mralQzFyaB97_UvjykNsVXKxRtT7FsQ1Ele8KKb5UnI6Mkf39axMJaw8n4v4HpEXnRB5i_4fu5oE&smid=url-share

title: 'Horribly Unethical': Startup Experimented on Suicidal Teens on Social Media With Chatbot

last_post.content:
"I have not in recent years seen a study so callously asleep at the ethical wheel. Dealing with suicidal persons in this way is inexcusable."

I knew Morris as a PhD student, and I'm sure this wasn't his intent. But as someone who studies & creates ethics procedures for online experiments, I completely agree with the critiques of this non-consented mental health study. Well-intentioned ignorance is a very dangerous thing.

https://www.vice.com/en/article/5d9m3a/horribly-unethical-startup-experimented-on-suicidal-teens-on-facebook-tumblr-with-chatbot

title: J. Nathan Matias 🦣 (@natematias@social.coop)

last_post.content:
Remember that mental health start up that was experimenting—without informed consent—with chatbots for people in crisis? They’re back in the news again.

@natematias has a detailed thread here https://social.coop/@natematias/109990388176345899

Not only is this study troubling for its own sake, but it highlights the fact that tech companies have so thoroughly normalized the notion of experimenting on all of us all the time that doing these kinds of studies with high-risk populations seems reasonable to them.

title: https://findmycite.org

last_post.content:
2/3) https://findmycite.org works by creating a custom prompt and asking an #LLM (#GPT3) to produce output based only on the trusted text in the prompt. It does this by using user input to run a semantic search that sources material for the prompt.¹ It's similar to what DuckDuckGo is doing with Wikipedia.²

It's very sensitive to the way we source materials for the prompt, but here's the thing, #GPT limits this prompt to ~4K words...

______
¹ https://findmycite.org/#bs
² https://spreadprivacy.com/duckassist-launch/

title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020 period, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Google Groups has been left to die

last_post.content:
If you're an organizer of any sort, it behooves you to think long term:

"This experience has been instructive for me. Once you start thinking on timescales of 5-10 years, communities built on proprietary software just don’t pass muster. Certainly self-hosted FOSS communities can die, but these are functions of community activity itself rather than the service they’re hosted on."

https://ahelwer.ca/post/2023-03-08-google-groups/

#Community #Organizing #OpenSource

title: Research in Germany - Two Minutes in a Research Wonderland!

last_post.content: If you thought last year's video by the German Federal Ministry for Education and Research (#BMBF) about early career researchers clogging up the system was bad, wait until you see their latest video about #Germany as a "research wonderland" (their words, not mine): It's all just shiny happy people! No pressure, no care work, no contracts running out, no rejections. – Watch here, no German skills needed: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=APNEiMyCJdM #ECR #ResearchWonderland #IchBinHanna #IchBinReyhan

title: bloomberg.com/opinion/articles...

last_post.content: Per Matt Levine, another bank is very likely to pay $1:$1 for SVB because SVB is *not* out of money—it had too many long-time, low-interest investments that it couldn’t unwind without incurring losses. A larger bank can absorb this in a larger portfolio and make a profit. Levine also points out that another bank will step up to prevent contagion. https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2023-03-10/startup-bank-had-a-startup-bank-run

title: ScummVM

last_post.content:
ScummVM for Android 2.7.0.2 (beta3) is out.

In order to join the beta program and help us with testing, please follow this link: https://play.google.com/apps/testing/org.scummvm.scummvm

If you are already enrolled in the beta program, then you'll get the update shortly via the Play Store.

The latest beta builds are also available on our website at

https://www.scummvm.org/downloads/

The Changelog is:
- Faster app loading time
- Fixed a number of reported app crashes
- Reintroduced support of devices at API level 16 (Android 4.1) as minimum
- Full release notes for 2.7.0 are at: https://scummvm.org/frs/scummvm/2.7.0/ReleaseNotes.html

title: Samsung "space zoom" moon shots are fake, and here is the proof

last_post.content:
Samsung is replacing actual pictures you take of the moon with a fake AI version that is crystal clear.

This is pretty terrifying. The phone software can identify objects in pictures and replace them.

How long until they're replacing the content of billboards in the backgrounds of your pictures with whoever pays for it? What if they decide you can't record encounters with the police, and it automatically blurs the face of the police?

title: Israeli troops fired into group of Palestinian civilians in Nablus

last_post.content: “The Post collected more than 1,000 photos and geospatial data of the site. This data was processed in photogrammetry software Metashape and exported as a scaled 3D mesh. The Post then used perspective plotting tools alongside available location and camera lens metadata from the collected photographs and videos to add virtual cameras into the scene, matching the perspective of key visuals from different angles, and assisting in the accurate modeling of the site.” https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/interactive/2023/palestine-shooting-nablus-videos/

last_post.content:
Omsom, a small business founded by two Vietnamese sisters, makes pantry sauces for Asian dishes and is now asking customers to place orders on their web site due to getting caught up in the SVB collapse. (They’ve opened a new bank account per their Instagram.) All their products are gluten free and a number are also vegan.

https://omsom.com

Edited to add:

Red Boat Fish Sauce is also doing a cash (!) giveaway to help support Omsom:

“Here's how you can win some damn delicious sauce for free:

(1) Buy a bundle from Omsom's website by 11:59PM PST tonight.
(2) Forward us your receipt: info@redboatfishsauce.com
(3) 50 winners will be randomly selected and venmo'd back for their purchase!

Please spread the word to your family and friends so we can all continue enjoying delicious Asian sauces 🍴”

title: Silicon Valley Bank Used Former McCarthy Staffers to Weaken Regulations, Lobby FDIC

last_post.content:
SVB lobbyists, many of whom had worked for prominent political figures like Bill Clinton, Kevin McCarthy, and Jay Inslee, convinced Congress to "exempt banks the size of Silicon Valley Bank from more stringent regulations, including stress tests aimed at uncovering the type of weaknesses that led to the bank’s implosion Friday."

This is what political corruption looks like.

SVB President Greg Becker also pushed for exemptions, and should be held liable, IMO.

https://theintercept.com/2023/03/11/silicon-valley-bank-used-former-mccarthy-staffers-to-weaken-regulations-lobby-fdic/

title: Chapter 12 Bias detection | Improving Your Statistical Inferences

last_post.content: Want to learn about p-curve analysis? My textbook chapter on 'bias detection' has a section on p-value meta-analysis: https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/bias.html#p-value-meta-analysis It will give you a complete overview of what these tests can and can not do.

last_post.content:
